{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3162597,"name":"Mike Stitt","username":"stittrm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/stittrm/{size}/175198_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-12T04:27:08.740Z","cooked":"

Is there a way to get an estimate of the standard deviation of a a limelight estimate of the robot pose from a apriltag fix?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-03-12T04:27:08.740Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":392,"reads":204,"readers_count":203,"score":2015.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":429920,"topic_slug":"standard-deviation-of-robot-position-from-limelight-and-apriltag","display_username":"Mike Stitt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/standard-deviation-of-robot-position-from-limelight-and-apriltag/429920/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3162681,"name":"","username":"dardeshna","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dardeshna/{size}/8532_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-12T09:29:14.722Z","cooked":"

I’m guessing you’re asking in the context of the wpilib pose estimators. I think the standard approach in FRC is to fix the state covariances and then tune the measurement covariances until you’re happy with the global pose convergence and noise rejection. The wpilib docs have some info on default standard deviations which might be a reasonable start:

The default standard deviations of the model states are 0.02 meters for x, 0.02 meters for y, and 0.01 radians for heading. The default standard deviations of the vision measurements are 0.1 meters for x, 0.1 meters for y, and 0.1 radians for heading.

As an aside, I’d imagine that the true measurement covariances depend on the pose itself. For example, if the robot is far from the target then the vision estimate will be more noisy. Or even if the target is head on versus skewed, that can affect the stability of the vision estimate. I haven’t seen this discussed too much on CD so maybe it is a non-issue in practice. I guess a straightforward fix is to only trust tags that are within some radius of the robot.

That helps point us in the right direction. We think our navx gyro heading drifts about 1 degree a minute. We are worried about the AprilTag heading errors messing up our trusted gyro heading.

How do teams select standard deviations for apriltag heading and position fixes?
